instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.I2C_BKLT_SDA: What is I2C_BKLT_SDA? I2C_BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL is a clock line on the data line between the system management controller(SMC), temperature sensors, GPU, and ALS(ambient light sensor). If this line is pulled down the machine may run slow or have the fans run fast all the time because the SMC can’t tell what the temperature of parts of the machine like fin stack are. Usual problem is bad webcam, unplug webcam to see if it fixes problem. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA is a data line between the system management controller(SMC), temperature sensors, GPU, and ALS(ambient light sensor). If this line is pulled down the machine may run slow or have the fans run fast all the time because the SMC can’t tell what the temperature of parts of the machine like fin stack are. Usual problem is bad webcam, unplug webcam to see if it fixes problem. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No v?deo - No Chime
threads.message:
I have a hard time to figure out the problem with this motherboard. If you guys can give me some hints,
i will really appreciate.

Water Damager near by <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> Replaced
Pin 1 = 3.3V
Pin 13 = 3.4v
Pin 2 = 3.3v  



<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
PP5VS5 = 5.1V
PP5VS0 = 5.1V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>XDP_JTAG_CPU_ISOL_L</SIGNAL> = 4.92V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> = 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> = 1.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.3

J8300
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> = 0V _ no short to ground
<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 5V


<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1.047V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.5V


<CHIP>U7600</CHIP>
Pin 15 = <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_BOOT_RC</SIGNAL> = 6.1V
Pin 1 = 1.05V
Pin 16 = 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No v?deo - No Chime
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12V"
Post the EXACT value there; 12.2V and 12.5V signify completely different things!

Do you get <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> voltage?
Check for USB activity before looking to get video.
See if all voltages from page 60 appear.

Disconnect anything from the MLB, including LCD and RIO board.
Use USB OSX pendrive (or mouse at least) to check if has activity.

<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is close enough to SMC.
You could have crap under SMC, or corrosion around J/<CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.
I recommend you to try new BIOS with clean ME too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No v?deo - No Chime
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1.7V
NO USB activity
SMC is pretty clean.

I think is the bios as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No v?deo - No Chime
threads.message: Prob bad CPU but could be BIOS
